Table of Contents

Enum ArticleStatus

Namespace
NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums
Assembly
NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll

Represents the user-facing status of an individual article within the RSS/Atom reader application.

public enum ArticleStatus

Fields

Archived = 3

The user has intentionally removed the article from active/inbox views by archiving it.

Behavior impact:

  • Hidden from main timelines, unread views, and per-feed lists by default.
  • Accessible only via "Archived" filter, search, or dedicated archive view.
  • Eligible for eventual deletion after a configurable retention period (to save storage).
  • Does not contribute to unread counters or clutter active feeds.

When assigned:

  • User clicks "Archive", "Done", or equivalent action.
  • Bulk archive operations (e.g., archive all read in a feed).

Typical transition: User can "unarchive"/"restore" back to Read or Unread.

Recommendation: Treat Archived as a soft-delete — keep metadata and content for search/restore, but exclude from most queries by default for performance and UX.

Read = 1

The user has opened, viewed, or explicitly marked the article as having been read.

Behavior impact:

  • Removed from default "unread" views and counters (unless user filters to show read items).
  • Still visible in "all articles" or chronological views.
  • No longer triggers new notifications.
  • Often grayed out or styled differently in lists to indicate completion.

When assigned:

  • User opens the article in detail view.
  • User uses bulk "mark as read" (up to current, all in feed, etc.).
  • Some clients auto-mark as read when article is visible on screen for X seconds (configurable).

Typical transitions: Back to Unread if user manually marks unread; to Starred or Archived.

Starred = 2

The user has explicitly marked the article as important, favorite, or "starred" for later reference.

Behavior impact:

  • Appears in a dedicated "Starred"/"Favorites"/"Saved" section or filter.
  • Often exempt from auto-archiving or cleanup policies.
  • Highlighted visually (star icon, different background/color).
  • May persist longer in local storage or sync even if original feed removes it.

When assigned:

  • User clicks star/favorite button on an article (from any prior status: Unread, Read, or even Archived in some flows).

Business note: In this model, Starred replaces the previous status (e.g., a Read article becomes Starred, not Read+Starred). If compound states are needed (e.g., read AND starred), consider a separate flags table instead of a single enum.

Unread = 0

The article is new and has not yet been opened or marked as read by the user.

Behavior impact:

  • Appears prominently in "unread" views, timelines, and feed lists.
  • Contributes to unread counters/badges.
  • May trigger notifications (push/email) depending on user settings.
  • Default sorting often places Unread articles first (chronological descending within unread).

When assigned:

  • Immediately upon successful ingestion/sync of a new article from the feed.
  • Never assigned automatically after initial creation.

Typical transition: User opens/scrolls past the article → changes to Read.

Remarks

This enumeration tracks the primary lifecycle and user interaction states for each article. It is used across the application to control visibility, filtering, sorting, notification behavior, and UI presentation of articles in lists, reading views, and dashboards.

ArticleStatus directly influences:

  • Which articles appear in the main "unread" or "all" feeds/timelines
  • Badge counters (e.g., number of unread articles per feed or globally)
  • Filtering options (e.g., "show only unread", "show starred", "show archived")
  • Sync priorities and cleanup policies (e.g., archived articles may be eligible for deletion after a retention period)
  • User actions like marking all as read, starring for later, or archiving to declutter

Status changes are almost always triggered by explicit user actions (via UI or API) rather than automatically by the system, except in rare cases such as bulk "mark all as read" operations. The status is persisted per-user per-article (typically in a database table linking user ID, article GUID, and status value).

Important business rules and design notes:

  • Statuses are mutually exclusive — an article has exactly one status at any time.
  • Starred is an orthogonal flag in many readers, but here it is modeled as a distinct primary status (meaning a starred article is no longer considered Unread/Read in the default view unless explicitly shown).
  • Archiving is a user-initiated "cleanup" action; archived articles are hidden from main views by default but remain searchable and restorable.
  • No automatic transitions occur (e.g., articles do not become Read just because time passed).
  • When a new article is first ingested from a feed, it always starts as Unread.
